child.geography: 10°S 166°-168°E; spoken on five small islands in th Duff (Wilson) Islands and the Reef (Swallow) Islands

child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1962): less than 500 speakers. “Linguistics information is inadequate, but better than for some other outliers. The dialects of Taumako and Aua, once phonologically different […], may be merging” (Biggs 1971:494).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “This language is spoken by an unknown number on two islands, Mele and Fila, in Vila Harbour, on the island of Efate, in the New Hebrides Condominium” (Biggs 1971:495).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: spoken on Aniwa and Futuna, small islands off the east coast of Tanna in the New Hebrides Condominium

child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “The total number of speakers in 1967 was about 500. The two dialects were said to be mutually intelligible in 1880 (Steel quoted in Ray 1888), and they are treated as dialects of the one language in Capell (1958)” (Biggs 1971:494).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1967): 250. “Linguistic information is scanty” (Biggs 1971:493).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 5°S 159°E, spoken in the Tasman Islands, Nukumanu being the largest
child.pub-comments: Population: about 100. “There is communication between Nukumanu and Luangiua. Linguistic information is scanty” (Biggs 1971:493).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population: about 300. “Published information on the language is scanty but Peter Sharples (Auckland University) has written a grammatical description and lexicon” (Biggs 1971:493).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Nukuria (alias Nuguria or Fead) consists of two atolls, with a population of Nukuria in the southern atoll of about 100. There were only 50 in 1907. There is little linguistic information, and what there is was collated by Ray [1912-21]” (Biggs 1971:493).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population: about 1,000. “Linguistic information is inadequate at present but Anne Thorpe (Auckland University) has written a grammatical description and lexicon” (Biggs 1971:494).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 12°S 169°E, spoken on the isolated high island of Tikopia in the Santa Cruz island group, plus on Russell Island, and in Honiara, Guadalcanal

child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 12°S 170°E, spoken on Anuta (Cherry, Anuda) Island, 70 miles northeast of Tikopia
child.pub-comments: “Little linguistic information is available but it is known that the language of the small population (200) is mutually intelligible with Tikopian and there was regular social intercourse between the two groups (Firth 1936:357)” (Biggs 1971:494).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population: perhaps 1500 speakers (Biggs 1971:494).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “The Futuna or Hoorn Islands are part of the French Overseas Self-governing Territory of Wallis and Futuna. […] The population in 1967 was 2,629. There are large numbers of Futunan speakers in New Caledonia” (Biggs 1971:491).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: Rennell Island 12°S 161°E, Bellona Island 11°S 160°E southeast of Guadalcanal island

child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Rennellese is an outlier language spoken on two small islands, Rennell […] and Bellona […] southeast of Guadalcanal. The two have a combined population of 1,760 (1963). Rennellese is one of the Polynesian languages for which Melanesian influence has been clearly demonstrated” (Biggs 1971:491-92).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 14°S 172°W. The total area of Western Samoa is 700 square miles
child.pub-comments: “The total population [of Western Samoa] in 1966 was 131,553. […] There are about 4,000 Western Samoans living in New Zealand, mainly in Auckland...” (Biggs 1971:492).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 14°S 170°W. The area of American Samoa is 76 square miles.
child.pub-comments: “...the population (1967) [of American Samoan] is 24,000, […] and an undetermined number of American Samoans living in the United States, mainly in Hawaii and California” (Biggs 1971:492).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Kapingamarangi is one of two Polynesian outliers in the U.S. Trust Territory of Micronesia, and is a ring atoll with a population of about 500” (Biggs 1971:493).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “A Polynesian outlier in the U.S. Trust Territory of Micronesia, Nukuoro is a ring atoll with a population of about 260 (1965). There are about 125 Nukuoro speakers living on Ponape. Many of the older people are bilingual in Ponape” (Biggs 1971:493).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 6°S-10°S and 176°E-180°E. Ellicean is spoken on seven of the inhabited islands of the Ellice Group which forms part of the Gilbert and Ellice Islands, A British crown colony.

child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population: 2,000 (Biggs 1971:492).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “(The gospel of St. Mark has recently translated into Southern Ellicean.) Southern Ellicean, according to several reports, is mutually intelligible with Tokelauan” (Biggs 1971:492).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Total population (1967): 6,124 (Biggs 1971:492). “There is some interference between the northern and southern dialects but most northerns are bilingual in the government-sponsored dialect of the south. Ellicean is not mutually intelligible with Samoan though many, perhaps most Ellicean speakers understand Samoan, which was used in church services because no bible translations in Ellicean were available” (Biggs 1971:492).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 21°S 167°E, spoken on Uvea in the Loyalty Island group
child.pub-comments: “Of a total population of about 2,500 (1963) an unknown proportion are speakers of a Polynesian language” (Biggs 1971:495).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Though Pukapuka […] is geographically and politically part of the northern Cooks, Pukapukan is not an eastern Polynesian language, being either Samoic, or coordinate with Samoic and Eastern Polynesian. Pukapuka is an atoll of 1,250 acres, with a population (1966) of 684. There are Pukapukans living in Rarotonga, and in New Zealand” (Biggs 1971:491).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 17°S 168°E, spoken in two villages on Three Hills Island in the New Hebrides Condominium
child.pub-comments: “Mae speakers number two to three hundred, and are said to be bilingual in Tongoan, a Melanesian language” (Biggs 1971:494).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 905
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 1,327. “Practically no linguistic information available except that it does not differ markedly from Rarotonga” (Biggs 1971:496).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 9,895. “Christian (1924:3) implies that the influence of Rarotongan as a standard dialect has overruled, many former dialectal differences but there is little detailed information to support this” (Biggs 1971:495). “Rarotonga is the administrative centre of the Cook Islands and its dialect provided the orthography for the official language” (Biggs 1971:495).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 2,617
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 293. “No linguistic information available other than that the dialect does not differ markedly from Rarotongan” (Biggs 1971:496).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 591
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 2,001
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 670. “No linguistic information is available other than that the dialect is not markedly different from that of Rarotonga” (Biggs 1971:496).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1966): 19,250 in the 13 inhabited islands plus at least 2,500 living in New Zealand (Biggs 1971:495). “Dialectal variation is considerable and the most divergent dialect, Penrhyn, is not readily understood by speakers of Rarotongan, for example. I have considered it advisable to list each island separately. The linguistic information from some of them is minimal, but it is known that they are all mutually intelligible with the exception of Penrhyn. […] Cook Islands Maori is partially mutually intelligible with New Zealand Maori though there is considerable interference occasioned by phonological changes, numerous lexical differences, and some structural variation” (Biggs 1971:495).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “The most marked dialect difference between the North Island Maori and South Island Maori (now extinct). […] Conquest of the South Island by North Island tribes early in the nineteenth century, the decimation and rapid linguistic absorption of the South Island tribes, and the lack of reliable information obscure the dialect picture” (Biggs 1971:497).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “The most marked dialect difference between the North Island Maori and South Island Maori (now extinct). […] Conquest of the South Island by North Island tribes early in the nineteenth century, the decimation and rapid linguistic absorption of the South Island tribes, and the lack of reliable information obscure the dialect picture” (Biggs 1971:497).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 44°S 177°W, spoken on the Chatham Islands, 500 miles east of New Zealand
child.pub-comments: “It is the only Polynesian language to have become extinct since Europeans entered the Pacific. Some Moriori texts and a short lexicon have survived. It seems probably that Moriori derives from New Zealand Maori (and from the South Island or an eastern North Island dialect)” (Biggs 1971:498).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Total Maori population over 200,000 of whom an estimated 100,000 speak Maori. All Maori speakers are bilingual in English. […] Maori traditions attest at least five centuries of intertribal contacts extending to both islands, which may account for the rather minor dialect differences in spite of the passage of at least a thousand years since New Zealand was first settled from tropical Polynesia” (Biggs 1971:497).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1922): 755. “There is little linguistic information and the language spoken at present appears to be a form of Tahitian” (Biggs 1971:496).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1962): 250. “There is no information later than 1921 for Rapa. It is possible that it too should be included with Neo-Tahitian” (Biggs 1971:487). “In 1921 (Stokes 1955) it was possible to distinguish an earlier Rapa dialect from the Neo-Tahitian also spoken” (Biggs 1971:497).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.geography: 22°S 151°W, one of the five inhabited islands of the Australs Group
child.pub-comments: “Linguistic information is scanty, but it is reported that the form of Neo-Tahitian spoken contains only seven consonant phonemes (see Table 1)” (Biggs 1971:496).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1959): Windward Islands 49,000, Leeward Islands 17,000. “Dialectal variation is minor throughout the Society Group and the language has undergone accelerated lexical change, especially in basic vocabulary, since 1800 (see Dyen et al. 1967, White 1967). Tahitian is a lingua franca for all of the Tuamotuan archipelago, the Marquesas, the Gambiers, and the Australs” (Biggs 1971:497).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1967): less than 7,000 plus 2,000 Tuamoatan speakers living in Tahiti. “All communalects are mutually intelligible. […] According to Stinson and Marshall (1964:21-4) there are (or perhaps were) six major dialects. The evidence presented for each dialect is scanty, and does not include any regular sound changes, nor other than minor structural differences, all of which are to be found in other eastern Polynesian languages” (Biggs 1971:498).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1967): 5,000. According to Biggs (1971:499), the dialects of Marquesan are mutually intelligible, and that “minor dialect differences occur among all the islands, and in the case of Nukuhiva, on the same island, but there is a major dialect boundary between the three northern islands of Nukuhiva, 'Uapoa, 'Uahuka (North Marquesan), and the southern islands Hiva'oa, Fatuhiva, and Tahuata (Southern Marquesan)” (Biggs 1971:499).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: Population (1963): 600-700.
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Hawaiian will be the first Polynesian language entirely replaced by a metropolitan language. At present it is spoken as a home languages only by the 250 or so Hawaiians on Ni'ihau and in a few scattered homes on other islands. It still has a certain social-ceremonial function, and Hawaiian may be heard in church services and on tourist occasions” (Biggs 1971:498).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “The population, as a result of Peruvian slaving and the introduction of smallpox was down to 111, of whom only 23 were women, in 1888. At this low point the presence of Tahitian missionaries resulted in the introduction of a sizable Tahitian lexical component” (Biggs 1971:495).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “An active volcanic island 13 square miles in area, Niuafo'ou is part of the kingdom of Tonga. In 1946, following a serious volcanic eruption, the 1300 inhabitants were removed to Eua Island, near Tongatapu. Many have now returned to Niuafo'ou and the present population is about 600. There is very little published information on the language, which is not Tongan though it is said to be partly mutually intelligible with Tongan” (Biggs 1971:491).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Niuatoputapu (alias Keppel) is part of the kingdom of Tonga. It is a small island of six square miles with a Tongan speaking population of 1400. The only published linguistic information is a short vocabulary dating from 1616” (Biggs 1971:491).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Uvea (Wallis Island) is part of the French Overseas Self-governing Territory of Wallis and Futuna. […] The population (1967) is 5,705. There are Uvean settlements in Noumea and Suva” (Biggs 1971:491).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “The three main groups Tongatapu, Ha'apai and Vava'u have a total population of about 75,000 (1966), of whom all but 1,000 are Tongan speakers. Dialectal differentiation is minor” (Biggs 1971:490).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.

child.pub-comments: “Politically part of New Zealand, Niue, a high island with an area of 100 square miles and a population in 1966 of 5,000 is linguistically close to Tongan. There are several hundred Niue islanders living in New Zealand” (Biggs 1971:491).
child.publications: Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
Biggs, Bruce. 1971. The Languages of Polynesia, Current Trends in Linguistics: Linguistics in Oceania, Current Trends in Linguistics, pt. 1 edn., vol. 8, 466-505. The Hague, Paris: Mouton.
